questionList.questionText: A 29-year-old registered nurse comes to the office due to sleep difficulties since receiving a promotion several weeks ago.  The patient's shift and sleep schedule changed when she took the new position; she now works from 7:00 AM to 4:00 PM.  Previously, the patient worked from 4:00 PM to 12:00 AM for many years and had no sleep difficulties.  However, she currently cannot fall asleep until 2:00 AM on a typical night.  The patient awakens by alarm at 6:00 AM to get ready for work and feels exhausted with pronounced sleepiness during meetings.  When she has time off, she sleeps from 2:00 until 11:00 AM and does not feel tired.  The patient has had sleep disturbances previously with jobs or schooling that required early start times.  She does not use tobacco, caffeine, or alcohol.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's sleep difficulties?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient's sleep patterns are consistent with delayed sleep-wake phase disorder, a circadian rhythm disorder characterized by consistent, unconventionally late sleep and wake times:

  • She displays a natural night-owl tendency to fall asleep and wake at unconventionally late times (eg, naturally sleeping at 2:00 AM, including on days off).

  • She had no fatigue or sleep symptoms when her previous schedule permitted significantly delayed sleep and wake times (eg, working 4:00 PM to midnight).

  • She has a history of sleep symptoms that appear only when she is required to wake up early (eg, current daytime schedule, previous jobs, schooling).

When patients with delayed sleep phase disorder fall asleep and wake according to their internal circadian rhythm, they have normal sleep quality and duration and no bothersome symptoms.  However, the disorder is typically unmasked when patients are required to conform to a schedule with early wake times, leading to bothersome symptoms such as daytime drowsiness, malaise, and gastrointestinal issues.

Diagnosis can be established with a sleep log with or without actigraphy (recording sleep patterns using a wearable device).  Management includes bright light therapy in the morning and slowly advancing sleep and wake times.

(Choice A)  Advanced sleep-wake phase disorder is also a circadian rhythm abnormality; it manifests with markedly early (rather than delayed) sleep and wake times (eg, drowsiness starting at unconventionally early times, naturally waking several hours before dawn).

(Choice C)  Total melatonin production naturally decreases with age.  Abnormally low melatonin stores, as seen in dementia, may cause sleep disturbances.  This patient's relatively young age and lack of sleep difficulties on weekends make this diagnosis less likely.

(Choice D)  Sleep hygiene focuses on improving sleep behaviors (eg, maintaining a regular sleep schedule, avoiding excess caffeine or alcohol use in the evenings).  Suboptimal sleep hygiene typically causes chronic sleep issues that persist regardless of schedule.  This patient consistently sleeps at 2:00 AM, and her sleep symptoms occur only when her schedule requires her to wake up early; she has no symptoms when she can sleep and wake at unconventionally late times.  Therefore, delayed sleep-wake phase disorder is a more likely underlying cause of her symptoms.

(Choice E)  Shift work disorder leads to acute sleep disturbances after patients work unconventional, typically nighttime, shifts that interfere with light-dark circadian cues.  In contrast, this patient's sleep condition manifests only when she works conventional daytime (eg, 7:00 AM to 4:00 PM) shifts and is present in any situation (eg, previous schooling) requiring early wake times.

Educational objective:
Delayed sleep-wake phase disorder is a circadian rhythm disorder characterized by a pronounced night-owl tendency with markedly late sleep and wake times (eg, 2:00 to 11:00 AM).  Patients have no sleep difficulties if allowed to follow their internal circadian rhythm by going to sleep and waking at unconventionally late times.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Insomnia

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Diagnosis, cause, and treatment approaches for delayed sleep-wake phase disorder.

questionList.questionText: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the office by her mother, who is concerned about her behavior.  Over the past month, the girl has awakened almost every night, come into her parents' room, and insisted on sleeping the remainder of the night in their bed.  The girl wakes up abruptly in a panicky sweat, crying and screaming, "I'm so scared; monsters are chasing me."  She breathes rapidly and shakes but is able to calm down after being consoled by her parents and hugging a favorite stuffed animal.  She started a new school 2 months ago.  Although the girl is shy, she enjoys school and has several good friends.  She is eating normally and plays on a soccer team.  Examination shows no abnormalities.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
This girl's recurrent awakenings with associated dream content and ability to be consoled are most consistent with nightmare disorder.  Diagnosis requires recurrent episodes of awakening from sleep with recall of highly disturbing and frightening dream content.  On awakening, the child is fully alert, remembers the dream, and can usually be consoled.  Although frightening, nightmares are typically transient and developmentally normal for most children.  Nightmares occur during rapid eye movement (REM) sleep and are more frequent in the second half of the night.

Sleep terror disorder, in contrast, is a non-REM arousal disorder characterized by incomplete awakenings, unresponsiveness to comfort, and no recall of dream content (Choice G).  Sleep terrors typically occur in the first third of the night and are characterized by marked autonomic arousal and amnesia for the episode in the morning.

(Choice A)  Nightmares are common in acute stress disorder, but there is no history of trauma exposure or characteristic symptoms of hyperarousal or intrusive symptoms while awake.

(Choice B)  Although starting a new school can sometimes be stressful, this girl is not displaying any emotional or behavioral problems apart from nightmares (she enjoys school, has friends, eats well), making an adjustment disorder unlikely.

(Choice D)  Although panic attacks can occur during sleep and produce abrupt awakenings, they are not typically associated with nightmares.

(Choice E)  REM sleep behavior disorder involves repeated episodes of complex motor behaviors or vocalization during REM sleep.

(Choice F)  Separation anxiety disorder is characterized by excessive fear or anxiety concerning separation from home or attachment figures.  Although this girl turns to her parents for comfort following a nightmare, there is no evidence that she has difficulty separating in general.

Educational objective:
Nightmare disorder involves recurrent awakenings from REM sleep associated with full alertness and dream recall.  It should be differentiated from non-REM sleep terrors, which are characterized by partial arousals, unresponsiveness, and lack of dream content.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Nightmare disorder

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Just a scary dream? A brief review of sleep terrors, nightmares, and rapid eye movement sleep behavior disorder.
Prevalence and correlates of disturbed dreaming in children.

questionList.questionText: A 28-year old woman comes to the office for follow-up.  She was seen a month earlier for evaluation of a year-long history of fatigue and leg pain.  The patient described "feeling tired all the time" and a sensation of heaviness and aching in both legs, unrelated to exertion.  Laboratory test results, including complete blood count, iron level, comprehensive metabolic panel, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and TSH are normal, and she says, "my other doctor also said all my tests showed nothing abnormal."  The patient has a history of childhood attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, treated with methylphenidate but has not required any medication since high school.  During college, she received supportive counseling for 2 months after being raped.  The patient does not smoke.  She drinks 1 or 2 glasses of wine or smokes marijuana most evenings to "relax after work."  Family history is significant for bipolar disorder in her maternal grandmother.  Vital signs are stable, and physical examination is unremarkable.  The patient describes her mood as "fine" and has a full range of affect.  Which of the following historical risk factors is most consistent with this patient's diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
Somatic symptom disorder

Risk factors

  • Female
  • Lower educational level
  • Chronic childhood illness or family history of chronic illness
  • Childhood abuse/neglect
  • Sexual trauma

Key features

  • ≥1 somatic symptom(s) causing distress/functional impairment
  • Excessive thoughts, anxiety, or behaviors (time & energy) related to symptoms
  • ≥6 months duration

Associated features

  • High health care utilization/multiple providers
  • Repeated testing rarely reassuring

Management

  • Schedule regular visits (not symptom driven) with same provider
  • Limit unnecessary workup & specialist referrals
  • Legitimize symptoms but focus on stress reduction/coping strategies
  • Antidepressants, cognitive-behavioral therapy if treatment resistant

This patient's history of medically unexplained, chronic somatic symptoms is suggestive of somatic symptom disorder (SSD).  Patients with SSD often consult multiple providers and undergo repeated laboratory testing with negative results.

A history of childhood abuse and/or adult sexual trauma has been consistently associated with the development of lifetime SSDs.  Other significant risk factors for SSD include female sex, low educational level, history of chronic illness as a child, and exposure to a family member with chronic illness as a child.  Concurrent medical and psychiatric disorders (eg, depression, anxiety) and difficulties with expressing emotions (ie, alexithymia) are also commonly associated with SSD.

(Choice A)  There is no known association of SSD with a family history of bipolar disorder, which is episodic in nature rather than chronic.

(Choices B and C)  Substance use is not a known risk factor for development of SSD.  There is no association of childhood attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and later development of SSD.  Childhood ADHD has been associated with increased risk of substance use during adolescence and adulthood.

(Choice E)  This patient is college educated.  Fewer years of education is a risk factor for SSDs.

Educational objective:
A history of childhood sexual abuse and/or adult sexual trauma has been consistently associated with the development of lifetime somatic symptom disorders (SSDs).  Other significant risk factors for SSD include female sex, low educational level, chronic illness as a child, or childhood exposure to a family member with a chronic illness.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Somatic symptom disorder

answerChoiceList.choice: History of alcohol and drug use
History of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Sexual abuse and lifetime diagnosis of somatic disorders: a systematic review and meta-analysis.
Psychological trauma and functional somatic syndromes: a systematic review and meta-analysis.

questionList.questionText: A 31-year-old woman comes to the office due to chronic abdominal pain that is unrelated to meals and has persisted for the past 2 years.  The patient reports no weight loss, nausea, vomiting, fever, or changes in bowel movements.  She has consulted several physicians and undergone endoscopy, colonoscopy, and CT scan of the abdomen, as well as an exploratory laparoscopy, all without any significant findings.  The patient was placed on sick leave because she has been unable to focus on anything other than her physical discomfort.  She is anxious and frustrated that physicians have been unable to arrive at a diagnosis and fears that she will be unable to return to work.  Other medical issues include obesity and tension headaches.  Family history is significant for hypertension and diabetes in her father, who died of colon cancer at age 59.  Physical examination shows diffuse abdominal tenderness on palpation and no other abnormalities.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
Key features of somatic symptom disorder & related conditions

Somatic symptom disorder

≥1 unexplained symptoms; excessive thoughts, anxiety & behaviors in response to symptoms

Illness anxiety disorder

Minimal to no symptoms; preoccupation with idea of having a serious illness

Functional neurological symptom disorder
(conversion disorder)

Neurologic symptom(s) incompatible with anatomy or pathophysiology

Factitious disorder

Falsification of symptoms/inducing injury in the absence of obvious external rewards

Malingering

Falsification of illness for obvious external rewards

This patient's persistent and excessive anxiety and time-consuming behavior in response to her abdominal pain are most consistent with somatic symptom disorder (SSD).  Patients with SSD typically consult multiple providers and undergo extensive diagnostic testing with negative results.  Although patients frequently have multiple somatic symptoms, only one (eg, pain in this patient) is required for the diagnosis.  The symptoms may be associated with another medical condition, and concurrent medical illness is not mutually exclusive.

SSD can be differentiated from illness anxiety disorder (formerly known as hypochondriasis) by the presence of significant somatic symptoms.  Patients with illness anxiety disorder have minimal to no symptoms (Choice C).  They are concerned primarily with the idea of having a serious illness.

(Choice A)  Conversion disorder (also known as functional neurologic symptom disorder) involves unexplained serious neurologic symptoms that are inconsistent with known neurophysiology, often preceded by an emotional trigger (eg, tragic event, argument).

(Choices B and D)  Both factitious disorder and malingering are characterized by the intentional falsification of symptoms, whereas patients with SSD are not trying to be deceptive.  Patients with factitious disorder have no obvious external reward and are motivated by the desire to assume the sick role.  In contrast, a diagnosis of malingering requires evidence of external benefit (eg, avoiding jail, obtaining disability benefits, obtaining narcotics).  There is no evidence that this patient has intentionally falsified symptoms and no obvious external reward.

Educational objective:
Somatic symptom disorder involves excessive anxiety and behaviors related to ≥1 somatic symptoms.  These patients typically have high health care use and undergo multiple tests with negative results.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Somatic symptom disorder

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Somatic symptom disorder.
Somatic symptom disorder, a new DSM-5 diagnosis of an old clinical challenge.

questionList.questionText: A 51-year-old attorney comes to the office due to sleep difficulties.  She is a partner in a law firm and finds her job demanding but enjoyable.  The patient goes to bed at midnight and has trouble initiating sleep.  When she cannot sleep, she checks the clock frequently, tosses and turns, and worries about being able to function the next day, eventually falling asleep around 3:00 AM before having to wake up at 7:00 AM for work.  She states that she is fairly productive in the morning but feels "exhausted" by midafternoon and often naps for 30-45 minutes after work.  She exercises around 8:00 PM several days a week and normally eats dinner around 9:00 PM.  The patient drinks several cups of coffee during the day but avoids caffeinated beverages after dinner.  She has 1 or 2 alcoholic drinks when she goes out with colleagues in the evenings once or twice a week.  She quit smoking 3 years ago but recently started smoking a pack a day.  On weekends, the patient tries to go to bed earlier and takes more naps during the day to make up for lost sleep.  She often wonders "what my life is all about" but tries not to dwell on these thoughts.  She also has been more irritable lately and feels sad at times, which she attributes to not getting enough sleep.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient with chronic insomnia has developed behavioral maladaptations (ie, poor sleep hygiene) that exacerbate her sleep issues, including the following:

  • Maintaining inconsistent sleep-wake times (significantly different schedule on weekends vs weekdays)
  • Taking late afternoon naps
  • Drinking caffeine in the evenings (should stop >8 hr before bedtime)
  • Smoking
  • Eating a late dinner
  • Exercising in the late evening
  • Remaining in bed and checking the clock frequently while awake

Initial management of chronic insomnia involves improving these maladaptive sleep behaviors (sleep hygiene).  Other components of good sleep hygiene include avoiding the use of electronic devices before bedtime; maintaining a comfortably cool, dark, quiet bedroom; and using the bed only for sleep or sex (rather than watching television or working).  Patients should also physically leave the bed if awake longer than 20 minutes.

It is also useful to address fears and unrealistic expectations around sleep (ie, sleep anxiety) through education (eg, temporary sleep disruptions are not detrimental, optimal sleep needs vary among individuals).  Collectively, this treatment has been standardized into cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia.

(Choice A)  Delayed sleep phase syndrome is characterized by a natural tendency toward sleeping and waking significantly later than conventional schedules.  Patients typically describe themselves as "night-owls" and are most productive in the late afternoon/early evening (in contrast to this patient).  Unlike this patient who sleeps excessively on weekends, when allowed to set their own schedule (eg, on weekends), these patients have normal sleep quality and duration for age.

(Choice B)  This patient does not experience chronic worries about multiple issues that are characteristic of generalized anxiety disorder.

(Choice C)  Although sleep disturbance is common in perimenopause, this patient does not report other symptoms of approaching menopause (eg, hot flashes, menstrual irregularities, vaginal dryness), making this diagnosis unlikely.

(Choice D)  Insomnia, irritability, feeling down, and thoughts about the purpose of life are consistent with dysthymia.  However, this patient enjoys work, socializes with coworkers, and has no other depressive symptoms (eg, anhedonia, guilt, loss of appetite, low self-esteem, hopelessness).  It is more likely that the mood symptoms are a consequence, not the cause, of her sleep disturbance.

Educational objective:
Poor sleep hygiene is a common cause of insomnia.  Strategies for improving sleep hygiene include maintaining a regular sleep schedule and a quiet, dark, comfortably cool bedroom; avoiding late afternoon naps and exposure to electronic devices before bedtime; and avoiding nicotine, caffeine, alcohol, and heavy meals in the evening.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Insomnia

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Nonpharmacologic management of chronic insomnia.

questionList.questionText: A 22-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of acne.  The patient has seen several doctors over the past few years for his "huge pimples" and has tried multiple nonprescription acne preparations without benefit.  He spends hours a day checking his skin in the mirror for new pimples and scars and researching the latest acne treatments.  He avoids socializing and dating due to fears of being rejected based on his appearance.  The patient purposely styles his hair to conceal his forehead and cheeks.  He has no medical history.  Vital signs are within normal limits.  The patient is wearing a baseball cap and hesitantly removes it.  Physical examination shows a small papule on his forehead and a few closed comedones on his nose that are noticeable only on close inspection.  His skin is otherwise clear without scarring or hyperpigmentation.  Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Body dysmorphic disorder

Clinical features

  • Preoccupation with ≥1 perceived physical defects
  • Defects not observable or appear slight to others
  • Repetitive behavior or mental acts performed in response to the preoccupation
  • Significant distress or impairment
  • Variable insight (good, poor, absent/delusional beliefs)

Management

  • Antidepressants (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors)
  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy

This patient's preoccupation with a perceived defect in his appearance and time-consuming, repetitive behavior is consistent with body dysmorphic disorder (BDD).  Common manifestations of BDD include disliking perceived appearance flaws in the following:

  • Skin: as in this patient who is concerned about significant acne despite barely noticeable comedones with no scarring or hyperpigmentation
  • Hair pattern: balding, too much hair
  • Nose: size, shape

Compulsions (eg, repeatedly checking one's appearance in mirrors) are characteristic.  Patients with BDD typically have poor insight and often request unnecessary cosmetic and surgical treatments to correct perceived flaws.

Treatment options for BDD include pharmacotherapy with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) (eg, escitalopram) and/or cognitive-behavioral therapy adapted for BDD.  Pharmacotherapy typically requires significantly high doses of SSRIs, which have been shown to decrease symptoms of obsessional preoccupation, compulsive behaviors, and associated functional impairment.

(Choice A)  Oral isotretinoin is typically reserved for severe, treatment-resistant acne due to its teratogenicity and multiple adverse effects.  It is not indicated for this case of very mild acne.

(Choice B)  Antipsychotic medications (eg, aripiprazole) are used primarily in psychotic and bipolar disorders and are not first-line treatments for BDD.  Patients with delusions involving perceived appearance flaws are diagnosed with BDD rather than delusional disorder and may have varying degrees of insight (eg, BDD with absent insight/delusional beliefs, BDD with poor insight, BDD with good insight).  SSRIs are first line in BDD, regardless of degree of insight.

(Choice C)  Reassurance and regular follow-up are important components of managing somatic symptom disorder, characterized by a preoccupation with physical symptoms (eg, leg pain, dizziness, bloating), and of illness anxiety disorder, characterized by fears of a specific illness (eg, cancer, lupus).  In contrast, BDD is characterized by an excessive preoccupation with appearance flaws (eg, acne, hair pattern) accompanied by compulsions; it requires high doses of SSRIs.

(Choice D)  Patients with BDD are rarely satisfied with cosmetic, medical, or surgical interventions.  This patient has already seen several physicians and has only mild symptoms that do not warrant the intervention of a specialist.  Referral to a dermatologist is not indicated.

Educational objective:
Treatment of body dysmorphic disorder consists of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors and/or cognitive-behavioral therapy.  Cosmetic treatments and surgery should be avoided.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Body dysmorphic disorder

answerChoiceList.choice: Reassure patient and schedule regular follow-up

questionMappingReferencesList.title: New perspectives in the treatment of body dysmorphic disorder.
Recent advances in understanding and managing body dysmorphic disorder.

questionList.questionText: An 18-year-old student is brought to the emergency department due to dizziness and weakness.  The patient was studying for final exams with her friends when she suddenly felt dizzy and started having palpitations.  She tried to get up but felt weak and had to sit back down.  The patient has had several similar episodes in the past 2 months.  She lives with her parents and commutes to a nearby college.  She has no prior medical conditions.  Family history includes diabetes mellitus in her father.  The patient reports occasional alcohol use.  Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 16/min.  There are no orthostatic changes.  BMI is 19 kg/m2.  Physical examination shows no abnormalities.  Finger-stick glucose is 48 mg/dL.  Symptoms promptly resolve with intravenous dextrose.  Serum insulin and C-peptide levels, drawn prior to dextrose administration, are elevated.  Which of the following best explains this patient's symptoms?
questionList.explanationText:
Factitious disorder (imposed on self)

Behavioral
characteristics

  • Intentional falsification of illness:
    • Feigning illness
    • Self-induced illness
    • Exacerbation of preexisting illness
  • Motivation by internal factors rather than external gain (eg, financial compensation)

Clinical
presentation

  • Overt/dramatic symptoms
  • Frequent visits for medical care
  • Patient possibly refusing consent to release records or tampering with test samples
  • More common in health care workers

Diagnostic
confirmation

  • Direct observation or discovery of medical supplies (eg, medications, syringes)
  • Confirmatory testing (eg, sulfonylurea screen, stool laxative screen)
  • Medical record review

This patient has symptomatic hypoglycemia, and the elevated insulin and C-peptide levels suggest that this is due to excessive endogenous secretion of insulin because C-peptide is cosecreted with endogenous insulin but not present in injectable insulins.  Although this could be due to an autonomous insulin-secreting islet cell tumor (ie, insulinoma), such tumors are very rare and usually occur at age >40.  Surreptitious use of a sulfonylurea or other insulin secretagogue is much more likely, particularly in a patient with a family member who has diabetes mellitus or other access to prescription medications (eg, pharmacy worker).  The diagnosis can be confirmed with a hypoglycemic drug screen.

Factitious disorder is characterized by intentional falsification of illness in the absence of external reward (eg, financial compensation, disability benefits).  Patients with factitious disorder appear to be motivated by internal factors, such as psychosocial stressors (eg, college workload, final examinations) or desire for validation.  A history of major childhood illness or abuse is associated with increased risk, but the etiology is poorly understood.  Treatment primarily includes psychotherapy.

(Choice A)  Binge alcohol drinking can cause hypoglycemia due to depletion of hepatic glycogen, impaired gluconeogenesis, and altered counterregulatory hormone (eg, epinephrine) secretion.  However, this patient's elevated insulin and C-peptide levels indicate excessive endogenous insulin secretion as the cause.

(Choice B)  Patients with factitious disorder may induce hypoglycemia by injecting exogenous insulin.  However, exogenous insulin preparations do not contain C-peptide, so levels would be low.

(Choices C and D)  Phentermine is a centrally acting appetite suppressant that can cause short-term weight loss in patients with obesity.  However, reduced caloric intake, whether due to anorexiants or simple dietary restriction, rarely causes severe hypoglycemia because of the induction of multiple counterregulatory factors (ie, glucagon, cortisol, epinephrine, growth hormone).  In addition, C-peptide would not be elevated.

(Choice E)  Self-induced vomiting (eg, due to an eating disorder) can cause dizziness and weakness due to the resulting metabolic derangements (eg, hypovolemia, metabolic alkalosis, hypochloremia) but would not cause increased endogenous insulin secretion.  Patients would often have orthostatic hypotension.

Educational objective:
Factitious disorder is characterized by intentional falsification of illness in the absence of external reward.  Patients appear to be motivated by internal factors, such as psychosocial stressors or desire for validation.  Patients with factitious disorder may have hypoglycemia due to the surreptitious intake of sulfonylureas or insulin.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Factitious disorder

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Psychological aspects of factitious disorder.

questionList.questionText: A 42-year-old woman comes to the office due to chronic insomnia.  She describes a history of intermittent insomnia since college but notes that it has worsened over the past several years.  On weeknights, the patient typically goes to bed between 11:00 PM and midnight but lies awake for 1-2 hours before falling asleep; she also frequently awakens at least once during the night and lies in bed for up to an hour waiting to return to sleep.  On weekends, she sleeps later to catch up on lost sleep but still feels tired "all the time".  The patient enjoys her job and is performing well, but often feels worried about her lack of sleep and has cut back significantly on social activities due to concern about needing more sleep.  She avoids caffeine and does not use alcohol.  The patient has a history of hypothyroidism treated with levothyroxine.  Physical examination is normal.  Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient with chronic insomnia has developed behavioral maladaptions (eg, anxiety about sleep, sleeping later on weekends, lying awake in bed for long periods of time).  Cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) is first-line treatment for patients with chronic insomnia to improve sleep behaviors; when implemented correctly, it can successfully resolve chronic insomnia without medications.

In CBT-I, patients are first instructed to keep a sleep diary (eg, bedtime, approximate time to fall asleep, timing and duration of nighttime awakenings, final wake time), enabling calculation of current sleep efficiency (ie, number of hours spent asleep / number of hours in bed).  Then, targeted strategies are implemented to increase sleep efficiency to near 100%, increase sleep drive, and strengthen the association between being in bed and sleeping.  Strategies may include:

  • Establishing an optimal and consistent wake and sleep time across weekdays and weekends (ie, avoiding sleeping late)

  • Limiting time spent in bed awake.  Patients should use the bed only for sleep or sex (eg, instead of watching television) and physically leave the bed if they are awake in bed >20 minutes.

  • Improving sleep hygiene (eg, moderating caffeine intake, limiting alcohol use before bed, addressing sleep anxiety)

(Choice A)  Going to bed earlier typically worsens chronic insomnia because it reduces sleep efficiency (eg, increasing time spent awake in bed waiting to sleep).  Typically, CBT-I initially involves paradoxically delaying bedtime (but keeping a set wake time) until sleep efficiency is 100%; gradually, bedtime is moved earlier until the patient achieves a sufficient quantity of sleep.

(Choice B)  Sleep difficulties can result from major depressive disorder, which is often treated with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (eg, sertraline).  However, this patient enjoys her job and has no evidence of low self-esteem or feeling hopeless.  Her reduction in social activities is more likely connected to her underlying preoccupation about sleep, and CBT-I should be tried first.

(Choices C and D)  Benzodiazepines and the nonbenzodiazepine hypnotic medication zolpidem can be used for acute treatment of situational insomnia.  However, long-term use is associated with adverse effects, including somnolence, dependence, and cognitive impairment.  Therefore, CBT-I should be tried first.

Educational objective:
In patients with chronic insomnia, first-line treatment involves cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) to improve sleep hygiene and sleep efficiency.  Patients should first keep a sleep diary, which helps to identify opportunities to improve sleep efficiency (eg, limiting time in bed) and establish an optimal, consistent sleep and wake time.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Insomnia

answerChoiceList.choice: Encourage the patient to go to bed 2 hours earlier each night
Prescribe low-dose alprazolam at bedtime, as needed
Prescribe low-dose zolpidem at bedtime, as needed
Recommend keeping a diary of sleep times for 1 week

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Advances in the management of chronic insomnia.
Cognitive behavioral therapy for chronic insomnia: a systematic review and meta-analysis.
Cognitive and behavioral therapies in the treatment of insomnia: a meta-analysis.

questionList.questionText: A 26-year-old woman comes to the office requesting referral for breast surgery.  She says, "I feel disgusted with how my breasts look," and she describes numerous cosmetic aspects of her breasts that she finds troubling, including their asymmetry, shape, and small size.  The patient says she has stopped going out with her friends because everyone stares at her breasts.  She spends 1-2 hours every morning trying on different outfits to "hide" her chest and has ordered multiple custom bras to make her breasts appear more symmetric.  The patient has no history of medical or psychiatric conditions and takes no medications.  Vital signs are within normal limits.  On physical examination, the breasts appear normal in symmetry, shape, and size.  There are no palpable breast lumps or axillary lymphadenopathy.  The patient says, "I really think cosmetic surgery would help me feel normal again."  Which of the following is the most appropriate initial response to this patient's concerns?
questionList.explanationText:
Body dysmorphic disorder

Clinical features

  • Preoccupation with ≥1 perceived physical defects
  • Defects not observable or appear slight to others
  • Repetitive behavior performed in response to the preoccupation (eg, mirror checking, concealing, excessive grooming, skin picking)
  • Significant distress or impairment
  • Variable insight (good, poor, absent/delusional beliefs)

Approach to patient

  • Acknowledge distress; do not refer to perceived flaws as "imagined"
  • Reassurance about normal appearance rarely helpful
  • Focus on alleviating distress & functional impairment
  • Avoid inappropriate cosmetic/medical/surgical treatments

Treatment

  • Antidepressants (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors)
  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy

This patient's excessive preoccupation with perceived defects in her breast shape, size, and symmetry is consistent with body dysmorphic disorder (BDD).  Patients with BDD typically engage in time-consuming behaviors to conceal the perceived defect and frequently become socially isolated due to fears that others will see and reject them because of their "deformity."  Most patients have minimal to no insight into their true condition (BDD) and seek surgical and dermatologic treatments to correct their perceived flaws.  However, surgery should be discouraged because patients are rarely satisfied with the results and BDD symptoms may worsen following the operation, leading to additional, inappropriate cosmetic procedures.

Responding to a patient with BDD who requests surgery requires engaging the patient and trying to build rapport before discussing the recommendation to avoid surgery.  The most appropriate initial response would be to acknowledge the patient's distress and focus on the impairment it causes without validating or dismissing the patient's beliefs about appearance.  In this patient, acknowledging how her time-consuming appearance concerns have negatively impacted her social life can help establish a therapeutic alliance and lay the foundation for educating her about BDD and treatment options.

(Choice A)  Reassuring the patient that her breasts are normal when she does not believe that they are will likely be seen as dismissive and invalidating, leading to a deterioration in rapport.  It is better to focus on the distress and the impairment that BDD causes, rather than disputing a patient's perceived flaws.

(Choices B and E)  Surgery should be discouraged in patients with BDD, and these statements imply that pursuing surgery is a reasonable treatment option.  A better initial approach is to acknowledge how appearance concerns have caused suffering, followed by educating the patient about BDD and the reasons for avoiding surgery.

(Choice D)  Although patients with BDD who undergo surgery are rarely satisfied with the outcome, this response is likely to frustrate the patient at this point.  This comment would be more appropriate after establishing rapport and educating the patient about BDD.

Educational objective:
Body dysmorphic disorder (BDD) involves excessive preoccupation with perceived appearance flaws and is often accompanied by poor insight and a request for surgical procedures.  The initial approach should focus on the suffering and impaired functioning without challenging the patient's beliefs about appearance.  Once rapport is established, the patient should be educated about BDD and its treatment.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Body dysmorphic disorder

answerChoiceList.choice: "Breasts are usually not identical in appearance; slight differences are normal and not a worrisome sign."
"Cosmetic surgery can increase breast size but is unlikely to resolve your concerns about shape and symmetry."
"It seems you would like to get back to doing things that you previously enjoyed instead of thinking about your appearance."
"I understand you would like to have surgery, but most patients with similar concerns are rarely satisfied with the results."
"This type of surgery is a personal decision; let's review the cosmetic options so that you understand the risks and benefits."

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Body dysmorphic disorder.
New perspectives in the treatment of body dysmorphic disorder.

questionList.questionText: A 39-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with sudden right leg weakness.  The patient's medical history is significant for gastroesophageal reflux disease, which provokes occasional heartburn after meals despite medication therapy.  She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs.  The patient's husband of 20 years recently died suddenly in a car accident.  Blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg, pulse is 82/min, and respirations are 12/min.  She has mild epigastric discomfort on palpation, but the rest of the abdominal examination is within normal limits.  Neurological examination shows normal muscle tone, normal deep-tendon reflexes, and no Babinski sign in the extremities.  The patient cannot lift her right leg off the bed while supine and is very worried that something is wrong.  She is able to stand without assistance from a sitting position and her gait is without abnormalities.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
Functional neurologic symptom disorder (conversion disorder)

Clinical

features

  • Neurologic symptoms (eg, weakness/paralysis, nonepileptic seizures, sensory disturbances)
  • Not intentionally produced (contrary to factitious disorder or malingering)
  • Findings incompatible with recognized neurologic conditions
  • Symptoms cause significant functional impairment
  • Often precipitated by a psychologic stressor

Treatment
options

  • Education about the disorder
  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Physical therapy for motor symptoms

This patient's sudden onset of neurological symptoms with examination findings that are inconsistent with the pathophysiology of known neurological disease suggests a diagnosis of conversion disorder (also known as functional neurological symptom disorder).  Common presentations include unexplained weakness/paralysis, nonepileptic seizures, aphonia, blindness, and paresthesia.  Despite their psychological origin, the symptoms are not feigned or intentionally produced.  Contrary to popular belief, patients may be quite distressed by their symptoms.  An indifferent attitude toward severe symptoms (ie, la belle indifférence) occurs with equal frequency in both conversion and true neurological disorders and therefore is not a reliable indicator of conversion disorder.

Common triggers for conversion disorder include relationship conflicts or other stressors with an intense emotional component.  First-line treatment includes education about the disorder, validation for the distress it causes, and support for patients and family members.  If patients do not respond to education, cognitive-behavioral therapy is a second-line option.

(Choice B)  Factitious disorder is the intentional production of physical or psychological symptoms with the goal of assuming a sick role; there is no evidence that this patient is motivated to assume a sick role.

(Choice C)  Illness anxiety disorder (previously known as hypochondriasis) is characterized by excessive worry over having or developing a serious illness while having very mild or nonexistent somatic symptoms.  Illness anxiety disorder does not present with the unexplained neurological symptoms found in conversion disorder.

(Choice D)  Malingering is the intentional production of false or grossly exaggerated physical or psychological symptoms motivated by external incentives (eg, unemployment benefits, money, narcotics).  External incentives are notably absent in this patient.

(Choice E)  Multiple sclerosis presents with neurological symptoms that correspond with demyelinating disease in the CNS.  This patient's presentation is inconsistent with known neurological pathophysiology and therefore would be incompatible with a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis.

(Choice F)  Somatic symptom disorder involves excessive anxiety about ≥1 physical symptom(s) lasting for ≥6 months and can occur in patients whose symptoms are explained by recognized diseases.  In contrast, this patient's symptoms and related anxiety are acute, seemingly proportional to the severity of impairment, and do not meet duration criteria.

Educational objective:
Conversion disorder is characterized by the sudden onset of neurological symptoms with clinical findings that are incompatible with recognized neurological conditions.  Conversion disorder is often precipitated by stress.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Conversion disorder

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Assessment of patients with functional neurologic disorders.
Conversion disorder—mind versus body:  a review.
Functional neurologic disorders.

questionList.questionText: A 36-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of intermittent chest pain and palpitations.  The patient describes episodes of pressure in her chest, occurring 2 or 3 times a week, lasting several minutes to an hour, and typically occurring while she is lying in bed.  She also has sensations that her heart is fluttering and reports, "Last week, during a work meeting, my heart started racing, and I felt dizzy for a few seconds."  Six months ago, the patient was evaluated by her previous physician for similar symptoms and was told, "Nothing is abnormal," but she adds, "They didn't test me when I have symptoms."  She has no other medical or psychiatric history.  The patient has eliminated all caffeinated beverages and does not use alcohol, tobacco, or illicit drugs.  She reports feeling excited about a recent promotion at work but feels "stressed out" because of increased expectations.  Blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg, pulse is 72/min, and respirations are 12/min.  Lungs are clear to auscultation and cardiac examination is normal.  Complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, TSH level, 12-lead ECG, echocardiography, and 2-week ambulatory rhythm monitoring are normal.  Which of the following is the most appropriate statement to address this patient's concerns?
questionList.explanationText:
Somatic symptom disorder

Risk factors

  • Female
  • Lower educational level
  • Chronic childhood illness or family history of chronic illness
  • Sexual trauma

Key features

  • ≥1 somatic symptoms causing distress/functional impairment
  • Excessive thoughts, anxiety, or behaviors (time & energy) related to symptoms
  • ≥6-month duration

Associated features

  • High health care use/multiple providers
  • Repeated testing rarely reassuring

Management

  • Regularly scheduled visits (not symptom driven) with same provider
  • Limit unnecessary work-up & specialist referrals
  • Legitimize symptoms but focus on stress reduction & coping strategies
  • Antidepressants, cognitive-behavioral therapy if treatment resistant

This patient's preoccupation with somatic symptoms despite negative workup is suggestive of somatic symptom disorder (SSD), a psychiatric disorder characterized by excessive anxiety and time-consuming behaviors related to thoughts about the seriousness of one or more physical symptoms.  Patients with SSD frequently and extensively use medical services and request additional testing.  Because normal results are rarely reassuring, patients with this condition typically seek care from multiple providers.

Initial management of SSD consists of arranging regularly scheduled visits with the same physician to develop the physician-patient relationship and minimize unnecessary testing, interventions, and subspecialty referrals.  Regularly scheduled visits that are not symptom driven (ie, do not require patients to develop worsening or new symptoms) are preferable because they help make patients feel that their concerns are being heard and decrease the number of emergency calls and visits.  By scheduling a routine visit in a month, the physician can monitor the patient, make judicious assessments regarding any further workup, and begin to shift the focus from physical symptoms to identifying psychologic stressors.  The physician can provide education on stress-reduction strategies with the goal of improving coping skills and daily functioning and discuss psychiatric referral if needed.

(Choice A)  This statement reinforces the idea that new or worsening symptoms are required for the patient to schedule a visit and may encourage inappropriate emergency visits.  In contrast, having scheduled visits empowers patients to manage their own symptoms, knowing that they are being heard and monitored regularly.

(Choice C)  Explaining to the patient that her symptoms are purely stress related would likely be perceived as invalidating because she is preoccupied with those symptoms and shows limited insight into any psychologic contributions to them.  This approach would risk damaging the physician-patient relationship.

(Choices D)  This patient has already undergone a thorough evaluation of her symptoms, including ambulatory rhythm monitoring.  Emergency department visits often lead to multiple unnecessary tests and should be avoided if possible.

Educational objective:
Patients with somatic symptom disorder benefit from regularly scheduled appointments, which establish a strong physician-patient relationship and minimize unnecessary testing, interventions, and subspecialty referrals.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Somatic symptom disorder

answerChoiceList.choice: "Everything looks fine, but please feel free to request an office visit if you are feeling 'stressed out' or develop new symptoms."
"Everything looks normal, but let's schedule a visit in a month to see how you are doing and discuss your symptoms again."
"Given repeated negative tests and your normal examination, we can be reassured that your symptoms are stress related."
"Your workup is completely normal now, but please go to the emergency room the next time you first notice the symptoms."

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Somatic symptom disorder.

questionList.questionText: A 58-year-old woman comes to the office due to abdominal pain.  The patient describes a long-standing history of abdominal discomfort characterized by intermittent episodes of cramping, bloating, and nausea.  She describes the pain as severe and disabling but has difficulty describing its quality or location.  There is no clear relationship to eating or specific foods.  Neither rectal bleeding nor melena is present.  The patient has seen 2 other physicians over the past year for similar symptoms but felt that her concerns were not taken seriously.  During review of systems, she reports headaches, fatigue, muscle weakness, joint pain, urinary frequency, anxiety, and insomnia.  She also reports losing 2.3 kg (5.1 lb) over the past year by following a low-calorie diet.  The patient does not use alcohol or drugs.  Vitals signs are stable.  Abdominal examination shows mild, diffuse abdominal tenderness to palpation that improves when she is distracted.  Physical examination is otherwise unremarkable.  Laboratory testing, including complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, lipase, Helicobacter pylori testing, TSH, and a CT scan of the abdomen, is negative.  When discussing the test results with the patient, which of the following is the most appropriate initial statement by the physician?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient has several clues suggesting somatic symptom disorder (ie, long-standing symptoms without a clear diagnosis, vague history of present illness, persistent thoughts about the seriousness of the symptoms, health concerns not alleviated despite consultation with multiple providers, exaggerated pain on examination).  However, when discussing the negative results of the medical workup, the physician must adopt a patient-centered approach and treat the patient with respect and tact.  This patient is worried about her physical health and test results.  At this point, she does not have insight that her symptoms may be caused or exacerbated by psychologic factors.  The most appropriate initial statement is to deliver the negative test results as good news that a serious medical illness has been ruled out.

Although it is important to eventually discuss the role of psychologic factors, the patient's coping style, and the diagnosis of somatic symptom disorder, initiating the discussion with statements like these would likely be perceived as dismissive and judgmental (Choices A, B, and D).  They may even lead to an unproductive debate about the cause of the symptoms and damage the physician-patient relationship.  The physician should initiate the discussion by acknowledging the distressing and real nature of the symptoms and providing the test results in a positive tone.

(Choice C)  Recommending counseling with another provider is premature and may be experienced as a rejection.  A discussion of how stress and coping skills can impact symptoms should precede any referral for psychiatric care.

Educational objective:
When medical workup fails to identify a medical etiology in a patient with suspected somatic symptom disorder, the results should be communicated in a positive tone assuring the patient that there is no evidence of serious medical illness.  The distressing and real nature of the symptoms should be acknowledged first, followed by a discussion of the suspected disorder and contributing psychologic factors.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Somatic symptom disorder

answerChoiceList.choice: "After reviewing your test results, I believe your symptoms are likely due to somatic symptom disorder, but treatment can help."
"All of your test results are normal.  Since there is no medical explanation for your symptoms, let's discuss your difficulty coping with stress."
"Although your tests are normal, I can understand that your symptoms are a source of anxiety.  Seeing a counselor can help."
"I understand your medical concerns.  But all your negative test results suggest that your symptoms are due to psychologic factors."
"I understand your symptoms are distressing.  The good news is your normal test results indicate that serious medical diseases have been ruled out."

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Somatic symptom disorder.
Medically unexplained symptoms.

questionList.questionText: A 68-year-old man is brought to the primary care physician's office by his wife.  She reports that the patient has been flailing in his sleep, particularly during the early morning hours.  She is worried that he will hurt himself or her with these movements.  The episodes started several months ago with infrequent nighttime movements but now occur almost nightly.  The patient's wife says, "It's like he can't control himself.  I have seen him kicking in bed, pushing over the nightstand, and moving furniture out of the way.  He has also tried to push me from behind with his whole body, all while appearing to be asleep."  She is able to wake him from these episodes, and he doesn't appear disoriented or confused on awakening.  The patient is unaware of his nighttime movements but describes a recurrent dream in which he feels lost and trapped in the woods and tries to escape.  He has had no behavioral symptoms while awake during the day.  His only other symptom is constipation.  The patient's medical history includes well-controlled hypertension.  Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination is normal except for slight slowness of gait.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
Rapid eye movement (REM) sleep behavior disorder (RBD) is characterized by complex motor behaviors that occur during REM sleep.  Normal REM sleep is characterized by muscle atonia.  However, in RBD, degeneration of the brainstem nuclei responsible for inhibiting spinal motor neurons during normal REM sleep leads to incomplete or absent muscle atonia, facilitating dream enactment behaviors.  These behaviors are more likely to occur during the latter half of the night, when the relative percentage of REM sleep is higher.  Patients can usually be awakened fairly easily and are alert and oriented.  They may not recall their movements during sleep but can often recall their dreams.

RBD is more likely to occur in older adult men.  If frequent and recurrent, it may be a prodromal sign of neurodegeneration with risk of subsequent onset of Parkinson disease or dementia with Lewy bodies.  RBD is frequently accompanied by prodromal signs/symptoms of neurodegeneration such as subtle motor deficits (eg, slowed gait), anosmia, or constipation.  Narcolepsy and antidepressant medication initiation are also associated with RBD.

(Choice A)  Nightmare disorder involves vivid recall of disturbing dream content.  However, unlike RBD, it is not associated with motor activity or sleep-related injury.

(Choice B)  Nocturnal seizures are characterized by repetitive and stereotypical movements.  They most frequently occur during non-REM sleep, a stage of sleep that is densest during the first half of the night, and are associated with postictal confusion on awakening.

(Choice C)  Obstructive sleep apnea presents with nighttime apneas, snoring, daytime sleepiness, or arousals related to respiratory effort.

(Choice E)  Restless legs syndrome involves an overwhelming urge to move the legs and is commonly associated with sleep disturbance and involuntary, jerking movements of the legs during sleep.  It would not explain this patient's dream enactment with complex motor behaviors.

(Choices F and G)  Sleep terrors and sleepwalking are examples of non-REM sleep arousal disorders that typically occur in younger patients during slow-wave (N3), non-REM sleep.  In contrast to RBD, they typically occur during the first third of the sleep period.  On awakening, there is a longer period of confusion before becoming fully alert, and individuals do not recall any concurrent dreams.

Educational objective:
Rapid eye movement (REM) sleep behavior disorder involves dream enactment that occurs during REM sleep due to absence of muscle atonia.  If awakened, patients become fully alert and recall their dreams.  In older patients, these behaviors may be a sign of neurodegeneration.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: REM sleep behavior disorder

answerChoiceList.choice: Rapid eye movement sleep behavior disorder

questionMappingReferencesList.title: REM sleep behaviour disorder.
REM sleep behavior disorder.

questionList.questionText: A 28-year-old graduate student comes to the office for follow-up of chest pain and poor sleep.  The patient continues to experience intermittent, nonradiating chest pain, especially in the evenings when he feels "tired."  He describes difficulty relaxing at night and takes up to an hour to fall asleep when he feels the chest discomfort.  The patient says, "I'm under a lot of pressure to work on my dissertation," and he is concerned that his chest pain and poor sleep are affecting his productivity.  The patient has no shortness of breath or systemic symptoms.  He has had similar symptoms for the past year and has been evaluated with repeated ECG and a complete laboratory and radiographic workup; all were negative.  Despite reassurance from the physician, the patient continues to be excessively worried about his symptoms.  His appetite is normal, and he denies feeling depressed.  The patient's medications include naproxen as needed.  He does not use alcohol or illicit drugs.  Physical examination is normal.  Which of the following medications would be most appropriate for this patient's condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Somatic symptom disorder

Risk factors

  • Female
  • Lower educational level
  • Chronic childhood illness or family history of chronic illness
  • Childhood abuse/neglect
  • Sexual trauma

Key features

  • ≥1 somatic symptom(s) causing distress/functional impairment
  • Excessive thoughts, anxiety, or behaviors (time & energy) related to symptoms
  • ≥6 months duration

Associated features

  • High health care utilization/multiple providers
  • Repeated testing rarely reassuring

Management

  • Schedule regular visits (not symptom driven) with same provider
  • Limit unnecessary workup & specialist referrals
  • Legitimize symptoms but focus on stress reduction/coping strategies
  • Antidepressants, cognitive-behavioral therapy if treatment resistant

This patient's excessive preoccupation and persistent anxiety about his symptoms despite appropriate medical evaluation and reassurance are suggestive of somatic symptom disorder (SSD).

General nonpharmacological management of SSD includes regularly scheduled visits with the same provider, avoiding unnecessary diagnostic testing and specialist referrals, exploring the role of psychosocial stressors on somatic symptoms, and promoting stress reduction and healthy behaviors (eg, sleep hygiene, relaxation techniques, exercise, diet, return to productive activities).

For patients who do not respond to general measures, treatment recommendations include cognitive-behavioral therapy and/or a trial of antidepressant medication.  The choice of treatment depends on availability and patient preferences.  Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (eg, citalopram) are commonly used as first-line pharmacotherapy, but serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors and low-dose tricyclic antidepressants can also be used.

(Choices A and E)  Benzodiazepines (eg, alprazolam) and zolpidem can be used in short-term treatment of anxiety and insomnia but are not indicated for management of SSD.  They would provide only temporary relief and carry risks of abuse/dependence.

(Choice B)  Buspirone is used to treat generalized anxiety disorder but has not demonstrated efficacy in SSD.

(Choice D)  The muscle relaxant cyclobenzaprine has a role in treating musculoskeletal chest pain associated with muscle spasm, but it is not used for SSD.

Educational objective:
General management of somatic symptom disorder includes regularly scheduled visits with the same provider and avoiding unnecessary diagnostic testing and specialist referrals.  Patients who do not respond to general measures may benefit from pharmacotherapy with antidepressants and cognitive-behavioral therapy.  Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors are generally used as first-line treatment.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Somatic symptom disorder

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Somatic symptom disorder.
Psychopharmacotherapy of somatic symptoms disorders.

questionList.questionText: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the office for evaluation of night awakenings.  The patient has awakened screaming 1 or 2 times a month over the past few months shortly after going to sleep.  When her parents go to her room during these episodes, she is short of breath, crying, and sweating, and her face is flushed.  The patient appears frightened, does not respond to her parents' attempts at comforting her, and continues to cry.  She eventually goes back to sleep on her own and does not recall the incident the next morning.  Until starting kindergarten 2 months ago, the patient stayed at home with her mother, and she no longer takes a nap during the day.  Although the patient reports that she is happy and enjoys making friends, her mother wonders if she is having nightmares due to underlying anxiety about starting school.  Developmental milestones are normal.  Temperature is 36.7 C (98 F), blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg, pulse is 96/min, and respirations are 20/min.  A complete physical examination is unremarkable.  Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Sleep terrors

Features

  • Abrupt arousals from sleep (panicked scream, terror, autonomic arousal, unresponsive to comfort)
  • Little or no dream recall
  • Amnesia for episodes

Management

  • Reassurance
  • Administer low-dose benzodiazepine at bedtime if episodes are frequent, persistent & distressing

This child's awakenings are suggestive of sleep terrors, a type of parasomnia that occurs during nonrapid eye movement (NREM) sleep, characterized by episodes of screaming and/or crying during which the child is inconsolable and cannot be fully awakened.  A flushed face, sweating, and tachycardia are common.  These episodes usually last a few minutes before the child settles back down to sleep.  The child usually has no memory of the incident.  Sleep terrors are most commonly seen in children age 2-12, with a peak incidence at age 5-7.  In healthy children with a classic presentation, the diagnosis is clinical and no further workup is required.  Parents should be reassured that sleep terrors are not dangerous and usually resolve spontaneously within 1- 2 years.

(Choice A)  Cognitive-behavioral therapy is not indicated for sleep terrors but can be helpful in the treatment of anxiety with related nightmares.  In contrast to sleep terrors, nightmares usually occur in the latter half of sleep when REM occurs and are associated with complete awakening and dream recall.

(Choice B)  Although sleep deprivation can trigger sleep terrors, there is no evidence that this child is getting inadequate sleep (eg, moodiness, behavioral change, daytime sleepiness).  As children grow, the necessity for daytime naps usually decreases.

(Choices C and H)  Desmopressin and imipramine are used in the treatment of nocturnal enuresis, not parasomnias.

(Choice D)  This patient's episodes are infrequent and do not result in functional impairment.  If episodes are frequent or interfere with daytime functioning, a low-dose benzodiazepine can be considered.

(Choice E)  If another sleep disorder such as sleep apnea or restless leg syndrome is suspected, a polysomnogram (PSG) should be performed.  Other indications for PSG include episodes with accompanying neurological symptoms (eg, stereotypies, staring spells), suggesting a seizure disorder.

(Choice G)  If restless leg syndrome is suspected, serum ferritin levels should be measured as iron deficiency can exacerbate symptoms.

Educational objective:
Sleep terrors are a common and usually benign parasomnia of childhood.  They occur during non-REM sleep and are characterized by fear, crying and/or screaming, and amnesia of the event.  The diagnosis is made clinically.  Parents should be reassured that episodes are self-limited and typically resolve within 1-2 years.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Parasomnias

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Sleep terrors and sleepwalking:  common parasomnias of childhood.
Just a scary dream?  A brief review of sleep terrors, nightmares, and rapid eye movement sleep behavior disorder.

questionList.questionText: A 22-year-old man comes to the office due to irregular sleep for the past 3 months.  The patient says, "School has become more stressful, and I have been feeling more fatigued since my girlfriend broke off our relationship last month."  He is often sleepy during the day and sometimes falls asleep unintentionally during classes.  The patient goes to bed at 1 AM and awakens at 9 AM.  After classes, he avoids socializing and frequently returns straight to his dorm room to nap.  The patient also describes "weird things happening as I fall asleep, like hearing whispering voices and seeing colorful animals."  He describes another unusual experience last week when he suddenly felt weak in his face and knees following an upsetting phone call with his ex-girlfriend.  The patient drinks beer socially but does not use illicit drugs.  He has a history of depression as a teenager that responded to psychotherapy.  Height is 170.2 cm (5 ft 7 in), and weight is 83.9 kg (185 lb).  BMI is 29 kg/m2.  Physical examination is normal.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Narcolepsy

DSM-5 diagnostic criteria

  • Recurrent lapses into sleep or naps (≥3 times/week for 3 months)
  • ≥1 of the following:
    • Cataplexy: brief loss of muscle tone precipitated by strong emotion (eg, laughter, excitement)
    • Low cerebrospinal fluid levels of hypocretin-1
    • Shortened REM sleep latency

Associated features

  • Hypnagogic or hypnopompic hallucinations
  • Sleep paralysis

This patient's excessive daytime sleepiness with lapses into sleep (eg, unintentionally falling asleep in class), hallucinations while falling asleep, and cataplexy (transient loss of muscle tone in response to intense emotion) are suggestive of narcolepsy.  Intrusions of REM sleep phenomena during sleep-wake transitions may include hypnagogic (on falling asleep) and hypnopompic (on awakening) hallucinations as well as sleep paralysis (inability to move immediately after awakening).

Narcolepsy is associated with low cerebrospinal fluid levels of orexin-A/hypocretin-1.  Onset typically occurs during adolescence or the early 20s.  Diagnostic evaluation includes polysomnography to rule out other sleep disorders and a multiple sleep latency test that demonstrates decreased sleep latency and sleep-onset REM periods.

(Choice A)  Adjustment disorder would not explain this patient's hypnagogic hallucinations and cataplexy, which are characteristic of narcolepsy.

(Choice B)  A diagnosis of narcolepsy requires ruling out other sleep disorders that can present with excessive daytime sleepiness.  Delayed sleep-wake phase disorder is characterized by a bedtime that is shifted later than desired with subsequent difficulty awakening at a socially, scholastically, or professionally mandated time, which results in shortened total sleep duration.  This patient goes to sleep late (at 1 AM) but sleeps for a normal duration and does not describe an inability to awaken at a preferred time.

(Choice C)  Hypersomnolence disorder is characterized by persistent daytime sleepiness (not sleep attacks) and is diagnosed only when excessive sleepiness is not better explained by another sleep disorder.

(Choice D)  This patient is getting a sufficient amount of sleep with 8 hours of sleep plus naps.  Insufficient sleep may lead to excessive daytime sleepiness, napping, and quicker REM onset, but it is not associated with cataplexy.

(Choice E)  This patient has insufficient symptoms for a current major depressive episode; his hallucinations are related to narcolepsy.

Educational objective:
Narcolepsy is characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness, cataplexy, and REM sleep–related phenomena (eg, hypnagogic/hypnopompic hallucinations, sleep paralysis).
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Narcolepsy

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Central disorders of hypersomnolence: focus on the narcolepsies and idiopathic hypersomnia.
Narcolepsy: a clinical review.

questionList.questionText: A 23-year-old woman comes to the office for a checkup.  She reports that a family friend was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis 6 months ago.  Since then, the patient has become increasingly preoccupied with the thought that she may have a neurologic illness.  She spoke with her sister, who briefly reassured her, but has since been unable to get the thought out of her head and stays up at night researching symptoms on the internet.  The patient double-checks food labels for preservatives and washes produce multiple times to remove pesticides because she read this could be linked with neurologic conditions.  She has noticed that her eyes get tired and that she has cramping in her fingers when she spends long hours writing on the computer.  She worries that this may be an early sign of multiple sclerosis and that she will not be able to support herself as a freelance journalist if she cannot write.  The patient has no psychiatric history but acknowledges that she is a "worrier."  Family history is significant for schizophrenia in a paternal uncle and anxiety in her mother.  Physical examination, including neurologic evaluation, is normal.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Key features of somatic symptom disorder & related conditions

Somatic symptom disorder

≥1 unexplained symptoms; excessive thoughts, anxiety & behaviors in response to symptoms

Illness anxiety disorder

Minimal to no symptoms; preoccupation with idea of having a serious illness

Functional neurological symptom disorder
(conversion disorder)

Neurologic symptom(s) incompatible with anatomy or pathophysiology

Factitious disorder

Falsification of symptoms/inducing injury in the absence of obvious external rewards

Malingering

Falsification of illness for obvious external rewards

This patient's excessive concern about having multiple sclerosis despite the absence of prominent somatic symptoms is consistent with illness anxiety disorder (IAD) (previously known as hypochondriasis).  Patients with IAD are preoccupied with the unfounded fear of having a serious, undiagnosed illness and are rarely reassured by negative findings on physical examination or laboratory testing.  Their fears of illness often become a central feature of their lives, leading to high health care utilization, repeated self-checking for signs of illness, and catastrophic interpretations of minor, nonspecific physical sensations (eg, thinking that eye fatigue and cramping after prolonged muscle use could signify a serious disease).

The treatment of IAD consists of scheduling regular visits, limiting diagnostic tests and referrals, and focusing on coping and functional improvement.

(Choice A)  Conversion disorder is characterized by neurologic symptoms and loss of function that are inconsistent with known disease.  Examples include weakness or paralysis in anatomically inexplicable distributions and nonepileptic seizures, unlike in this patient who has vague, nonspecific symptoms.

(Choice B)  Patients with delusional disorder, somatic type, have false, fixed beliefs about the body.  In contrast, patients with IAD are not delusional and can acknowledge the possibility that they do not have the disease, such as this patient who was briefly reassured by her sister.

(Choice C)  Patients with generalized anxiety disorder may have illness anxiety but also worry excessively about multiple everyday issues (eg, relationships, work, finances).  This patient's anxiety appears to be restricted to fears of having a serious illness and its implications.

(Choice E)  Although this patient has intrusive thoughts and checking behaviors (eg, seeking reassurance, checking labels, washing foods), these revolve around her preoccupation with disease.  She lacks the compulsive behaviors involving other concerns that characterize obsessive-compulsive disorder (eg, checking locks, counting, excessive handwashing).  IAD is diagnosed when the predominant concerns are restricted to health and disease.

(Choice F)  Patients with somatic symptom disorder have prominent somatic symptoms (eg, pain, gastrointestinal distress, sexual dysfunction).  In contrast, those with IAD are preoccupied with the idea of being sick and have minimal or no somatic symptoms, as seen in this patient who has mild, nonspecific symptoms.

Educational objective:
Illness anxiety disorder is characterized by excessive concern about having a serious, undiagnosed disease despite minimal or no somatic symptoms.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Illness anxiety disorder

questionMappingReferencesList.title: DSM-5 illness anxiety disorder and somatic symptom disorder: comorbidity, correlates, and overlap with DSM-IV hypochondriasis.
Attribution of somatic symptoms in hypochondriasis.

questionList.questionText: A 23-year-old woman comes to the office due to skin concerns.  The patient states, "I have pockmarks on my nose from having acne as a teenager."  She has tried high-dose retinol creams and skin-resurfacing procedures with no improvement.  The patient applies concealer to her nose every morning and has been late to work multiple times due to her routine.  She touches up her makeup throughout the day and is concerned that her supervisor has started to notice her frequent trips to the bathroom.  Vital signs are within normal limits.  Skin examination shows pores of minimal size, if any, on the nose and forehead; no acne or scarring is visible.  The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.  Which of the following is the most appropriate statement?
questionList.explanationText:
Body dysmorphic disorder

Clinical features

  • Preoccupation with ≥1 perceived physical defects
  • Defects not observable or appear slight to others
  • Repetitive behavior performed in response to the preoccupation (eg, mirror checking, concealing, excessive grooming, skin picking)
  • Significant distress or impairment
  • Variable insight (good, poor, absent/delusional beliefs)

Approach to patient

  • Acknowledge distress; do not refer to perceived flaws as "imagined"
  • Reassurance about normal appearance rarely helpful
  • Focus on alleviating distress & functional impairment
  • Avoid inappropriate cosmetic/medical/surgical treatments

Treatment

  • Antidepressants (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors)
  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy

This patient's excessive preoccupation with a slight or nonexistent defect in physical appearance (ie, belief that her nose is scarred from acne) is consistent with body dysmorphic disorder (BDD).  In response to appearance concerns, patients with BDD engage in time-consuming behaviors, such as this patient repeatedly examining her appearance in the mirror and reapplying makeup to conceal her perceived defects.

Patients with BDD typically have limited insight into their condition and therefore require a sensitive and tactful assessment approach.  The physician should acknowledge their distress and avoid referring to perceived defects as "imagined" or arguing with them about their appearance.  Physicians should empathize with patients' efforts to cope with their condition and determine their level of insight by gently exploring their perceptions of how others see them.  In BDD, insight can range from fair to good (patient acknowledges beliefs about appearance are possibly or probably not true) to poor to absent (patient thinks beliefs about appearance are probably or definitely true).

(Choice A)  Patients with BDD are rarely reassured when told that their appearance is normal.  They may feel that such statements minimize or ignore their concerns.

(Choice B)  This statement both validates the patient's concerns (by normalizing preoccupations about nasal skin) and inquires about past treatments, making it seem as if the physician agrees that something is wrong with her appearance.  This approach may inadvertently reinforce her concerns.

(Choice C)  Applying only moisturizer and sunscreen does not address the underlying issue of BDD, so this recommendation is unlikely to be helpful to the patient.  It is also misleading to describe the patient's skin as irritated when examination shows no abnormalities.

(Choice E)  This statement directly challenges the patient's perception of her appearance, which is likely counterproductive to developing a collaborative physician-patient relationship.

Educational objective:
Body dysmorphic disorder is characterized by preoccupation with slight to nonexistent appearance flaws and related repetitive behaviors such as checking, comparing with others, and camouflaging the perceived defect.  Assessment requires a sensitive approach that acknowledges patients' distress and explores the level of their insight while avoiding direct confrontation or referring to perceived defects as "imagined."
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Body dysmorphic disorder

answerChoiceList.choice: "It's common to feel self-conscious about appearance from time to time, but your skin looks healthy and normal."
"Nasal skin can be a problem area for lots of people; has anything you've tried in the past been helpful for your skin?"
"Skin can be irritated by recurrent makeup applications; I recommend applying only moisturizer and sunscreen to see if that helps."
"You have concerns about how your nose appears; if we were to ask other people about your nose, what would they say?"
"Your skin does not seem to have any scarring on examination; is it possible that these appearance flaws are only noticeable to you?"

questionMappingReferencesList.title: New perspectives in the treatment of body dysmorphic disorder.
Recent advances in understanding and managing body dysmorphic disorder.
