questionList.questionText: A 34-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to sudden-onset tingling and numbness in her left hand.  The patient is an assistant chef at a nearby restaurant and was lifting a box earlier in the day when she heard a pop and her left hand went numb.  She describes the numbness as "pins and needles."  The patient asks for a doctor's note to excuse her from work today, expressing concern that her condition will worsen if she does not take time off to heal.  Medical history is insignificant.  The patient allows the nurse to take her vital signs but becomes agitated when the physician attempts to examine her, insisting that an examination will worsen her discomfort.  Temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg, pulse is 72/min, and respirations are 16/min.  The numbness is in a glove distribution: the fingers, entire left hand, and wrist are numb, with normal sensation proximal to the wrist.  No edema or skin changes are noted.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
Psychosomatic disorders

Malingering

  • Intentional falsification or exaggeration of illness
  • Goal: secondary gain (eg, narcotics, shelter)

Factitious disorder

  • Intentional fabrication of symptoms or self-imposed injury or illness
  • Goal: assume sick role (no tangible secondary gain)

Functional neurological symptom disorder (conversion disorder)

  • Unintentional neurologic symptom(s) incompatible with anatomy or pathophysiology
  • Goal: no specific goal (often associated with comorbid psychiatric illness)

This patient reports a left hand injury sustained while lifting a box.  However, her sensory symptoms of numbness in a glove distribution do not follow an anatomic distribution of innervation.  This marked disparity between the patient's reported symptoms and known nerve pathways should raise suspicion for a psychosomatic disorder.

Psychosomatic disorders, which are differentiated by whether the symptoms are intentional and whether secondary gain is being sought, include:

  • Malingering:  feigned or grossly exaggerated physical or psychological symptoms reported with the intention of obtaining secondary gain (eg, leave from work, narcotics)
  • Factitious disorder:  false physical or psychological signs/symptoms intentionally produced to assume the sick role (rather than achieve tangible secondary gain) (Choice C)
  • Conversion disorder:  unexplained neurologic signs/symptoms that are incompatible with recognized neurologic conditions; differentiated from malingering and factitious disorder by the lack of external incentive (ie, secondary gain) and intentionally produced symptoms (Choice B)

This patient appears to be malingering.  In addition to the clinical inconsistencies, she is reluctant to allow the necessary physical examination and requests a work note.  This behavior suggests she is feigning symptoms for secondary gain.  Patients with malingering should not be directly confronted about their behavior.  Rather, they should be told that physiologic causes of their conditions have been excluded and their requests (secondary gain) (eg, providing a note for work) cannot be granted.

(Choice A)  Symptoms of complex regional pain syndrome typically begin 4-6 weeks after a traumatic extremity injury and include severe pain, swelling, sensory abnormalities, motor deficits, and changes in skin color or temperature.

(Choice D)  In a lunate dislocation, volar displacement of the lunate can compress the median nerve, usually causing a progressive neuropathy in a specific distribution.  In contrast, this patient's numbness began suddenly and involves her whole hand; lunate dislocations also typically require a high-energy force (eg, fall from height).

(Choice F)  A scaphoid fracture typically occurs after a fall on an outstretched hand; lifting a box is an extremely unlikely mechanism for this injury.  Although pain and swelling at the thumb base are typical, numbness and tingling are not.

Educational objective:
Malingering is the intentional production or exaggeration of physical or psychological symptoms for secondary gain.  Malingering should be suspected when a patient is reluctant to be examined and there is a discrepancy between reported symptoms and objective findings.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Malingering

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Malingering in the emergency setting.
Factitious disorders and malingering: challenges for clinical assessment and management.
